Cranberry Sauce with Apples

Jump to Recipe

Cranberry sauce is a quintessential component of holiday feasts, offering a delightful balance of tartness and sweetness that complements savory dishes perfectly. This Cranberry Sauce with Apples recipe elevates the traditional sauce with the addition of fresh apples, creating a rich, flavorful blend that will tantalize your taste buds. Bursting with vibrant flavors, this homemade cranberry sauce is not only easy to prepare but also a healthier alternative to store-bought options packed with preservatives. With just a handful of simple ingredients, including fresh cranberries, crisp apples, sugar, and a hint of cinnamon, you'll have a festive side dish that enhances any meal. Whether you're serving it alongside turkey for Thanksgiving or enjoying it with your favorite roast, this cranberry sauce will surely be a hit at your dinner table. Join us as we guide you through the steps to create this deliciously sweet and tangy sauce that will have everyone asking for seconds!

Ingredients

fresh cranberries

Choose firm, plump cranberries without any blemishes. If fresh cranberries are unavailable, you can substitute with frozen cranberries—just do not thaw them before cooking as they will lose their shape. Fresh cranberries can be rinsed and sorted to remove any bad ones before use.

apple (peeled and diced)

For this recipe, tart apples like Granny Smith or Honeycrisp work well as they balance the sweetness of the sugar. If you prefer a sweeter sauce, you could use a Fuji or Gala apple. Make sure to peel and dice the apple evenly to ensure it cooks at the same rate as the cranberries.

sugar

You can adjust the sweetness to your taste by using less sugar or substituting with honey or maple syrup. For a lower-calorie option, consider using a sugar substitute like Stevia or Agave syrup, but be aware that this may change the flavor profile slightly.

water

Water is essential for dissolving the sugar and creating the right consistency for the sauce. If you want to enhance the flavor, you can replace the water with apple juice or cider, which will complement the cranberries and apples nicely.

cinnamon

Cinnamon adds warmth and depth to the sauce. For a more complex flavor, consider adding a pinch of nutmeg or allspice. If you prefer a different spice profile, you could also use pumpkin pie spice. Ensure to mix well so that the spices are evenly distributed throughout the sauce.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Ingredients

    Gather all your ingredients: 12 ounces of fresh cranberries, 1 medium apple (peeled and diced), 1 cup of sugar, 1 cup of water, and 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon. Make sure the cranberries are fresh; if they are soft or wrinkled, discard them.

  • Step 2: Dissolve Sugar in Water

    In a medium saucepan, combine 1 cup of water and 1 cup of sugar over medium heat. Stir constantly until the sugar is completely dissolved. This step is crucial as it prevents any grainy texture in your sauce.

  • Step 3: Add Cranberries and Apples

    Once the sugar is dissolved, add the 12 ounces of fresh cranberries and the diced apple to the saucepan. Stir well to combine all the ingredients.

  • Step 4: Incorporate Cinnamon and Boil

    Stir in 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon into the mixture. Increase the heat to bring the mixture to a boil. Keep an eye on it to prevent it from boiling over.

  • Step 5: Simmer the Mixture

    After it reaches a boil, reduce the heat to low and let the mixture simmer for about 10-15 minutes. During this time, the cranberries will start to burst and the sauce will thicken. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.

  • Step 6: Cool and Serve

    Once the sauce has thickened and the cranberries have burst, remove the saucepan from heat. Allow the cranberry sauce to cool down to room temperature before serving. This will enhance the flavors.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I prepare fresh cranberries for cooking?

Rinse the cranberries under cold water to remove any dirt or debris. Check for any spoiled berries and discard them before using.

What kind of apples should I use for cranberry sauce?

You can use any sweet-tart apple, like Granny Smith or Honeycrisp. These will add a nice flavor and texture to the sauce.

How do I know when the cranberries are done cooking?

The cranberries will start to pop open, and the sauce will thicken as it simmers. This usually takes about 10-15 minutes.

Can I adjust the sweetness of the sauce?

Absolutely! If you prefer a less sweet sauce, start with 3/4 cup of sugar and taste as it cooks, adding more if desired.

Is it safe to eat raw cranberries?

While raw cranberries are safe to eat, they are quite tart. Cooking them in the sauce will enhance their flavor and make them more enjoyable.

What should I do if my sauce is too thick?

If your cranberry sauce becomes too thick, you can add a little water, a tablespoon at a time, while stirring until you reach your desired consistency.

How can I store leftover cranberry sauce?

Once cooled, store the cranberry sauce in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to two weeks. It can also be frozen for longer storage.

Can I add other spices or flavors to the sauce?

Definitely! You can experiment with adding nutmeg, orange zest, or even a splash of vanilla extract for extra flavor.

What if I don't have fresh cranberries?

You can use frozen cranberries in place of fresh. Just use them straight from the freezer without thawing.

Is it necessary to peel the apples?

Peeling is optional! If you like a bit of texture, you can leave the skin on, just be sure to wash them thoroughly.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This cranberry sauce is naturally gluten-free and can be made vegan by replacing the sugar with a plant-based sweetener like agave or maple syrup. For a lower-sugar option, consider using a sugar substitute suitable for cooking. Additionally, you can omit the sugar entirely for a more tart sauce, enhancing the natural flavors of the cranberries and apples.

Pairings

Cranberry Sauce with Apples pairs wonderfully with roasted turkey or chicken, providing a sweet-tart contrast that enhances the savory flavors of the meat. For a vegetarian option, serve it alongside a nut roast or stuffed acorn squash. As for beverages, consider serving it with a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a light-bodied red such as Pinot Noir. For non-alcoholic options, a sparkling apple cider or herbal tea would complement the dish nicely.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the cranberry sauce warm or at room temperature in a decorative bowl to enhance the presentation. Garnish with a few whole cranberries or a sprinkle of cinnamon for visual appeal. For a modern twist, consider serving it in small jars as individual portions, perfect for holiday gatherings or potlucks. This sauce also makes a delightful topping for cream cheese on crackers for an appetizer.

Cranberry Sauce with Apples

30 min
$5
150 kcal
Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 4

Description

A sweet and tangy cranberry sauce with the added flavor of fresh apples, perfect for any meal!

Ingredients

  • fresh cranberries: 12 ounces
  • apple (peeled and diced): 1 medium
  • sugar: 1 cup
  • water: 1 cup
  • cinnamon: 1/2 teaspoon
